The mechanism of formation includes an uncoordinated swallowing mechanism, which results in muscle spasms of the cricopharyngeus leading to pulsion diverticula as the wall of the hypopharynx and superior esophagus weakens. Risk factors for acute ischemic colitis include older age, coronary artery disease, hypercoagulability, peripheral arterial disease, or recent endovascular surgery. Typical symptoms of patients with acute ischemic colitis include crampy abdominal pain, tenderness over the affected bowel, and hematochezia. Treatment typically involves supportive care, anticoagulation, antibiotics, and surgery in cases of bowel infarction, necrosis, or perforation.
